revision.text:
{{use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Infobox feature on celestial object |name = Ahuna Mons |pronunciation = {{IPAc-en|@|'|h|u:|n|@|_|'|m|Q|n|z}} |image = Lone conical mountain on Ceres from HAMO.jpg |caption = The mountain imaged by the [[Dawn (spacecraft)|''Dawn'']] spacecraft. North is down. |location = [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]] |coordinates= {{coord|10.46|S|315.8|E|globe:ceres_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} |peak = about 4 km (2 mi or 13,000 ft) high |discoverer = ''[[Dawn (spacecraft)|Dawn]]'' spacecraft team
2015 |eponym = [[Sumi Naga#Ahuna|Ahuna]], harvest festival of the [[Sumi Naga]] from [[India]]. }} '''Ahuna Mons'''[http://planetarynames.wr.usgs.gov/Feature/15409 Gazetteer of Planetary Nomenclature – Ahuna Mons] {{IPAc-en|@|'|h|u:|n|@|_|'|m|Q|n|z}} is the largest mountain on the dwarf planet and asteroid [[Ceres (dwarf planet)|Ceres]]. It protrudes above otherwise smooth terrain, it is not an impact feature, and it appears to be the only mountain of its kind on Ceres. Bright streaks run top to bottom on its slopes; these streaks are thought to be salt, similar to the better known [[Bright spots on Ceres|Cererian bright spots]],{{cite news |last=Stone |first=Maddie |url=https://gizmodo.com/ceres-mysterious-bright-spots-arent-made-of-ice-after-a-1734112941 |title=Ceres' Mysterious Bright Spots Aren't Made of Ice After All |work=Gizmodo |date=1 October 2015 |accessdate=25 March 2016}} and likely resulted from cryovolcanic activity from Ceres's interior.{{cite news |last=Burnham |first=Robert |url=https://asunow.asu.edu/20151215-deep-freeze-puts-squeeze-dwarf-planet-ceres |title=Deep freeze puts the squeeze on dwarf planet Ceres |work=[[Arizona State University]] |date=15 December 2015 |accessdate=25 March 2016}} It is named after the traditional post-harvest festival ''[[Sumi Naga#Ahuna|Ahuna]]'' of the [[Sumi Naga]] people of [[India]]. In July 2018, NASA released a comparison of physical features, including Ahuna Mons, found on Ceres with similar ones present on Earth.{{cite web |last1=Landau |first1=Elizabeth |last2=McCartney |first2=Gretchen |title=What Looks Like Ceres on Earth? |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7196 |date=24 July 2018 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=25 July 2018 }} ==Discovery== The mountain was discovered on images taken by the [[Dawn (spacecraft)|''Dawn'' spacecraft]] in orbit around Ceres in 2015.{{cite web |title=NASA spies 3-mile-tall 'pyramid,' more bright spots on Ceres |url=http://www.cnet.com/uk/news/3-mile-tall-pyramid-more-bright-spots-spied-on-ceres/|date=17 June 2015|work=Cnet|accessdate=19 June 2015}} It is estimated to have an average height of about {{convert|4|km|mi ft|abbr=on}} and a maximum height of about {{convert|5|km|mi ft|abbr=on}} on its steepest side; it is about {{convert|20|km|mi ft|abbr=on}} wide at the base.{{cite web |title=PIA20348: Ahuna Mons Seen from LAMO |url=http://photojournal.jpl.nasa.gov/catalog/PIA20348 |date=7 March 2016 |publisher=[[Jet Propulsion Lab]] |accessdate=14 April 2016}} ==Origin== It has been proposed that Ahuna Mons formed as a [[cryovolcanic]] dome.{{cite journal|last1=Skibba|first1=R.|title=Giant ice volcano spotted on dwarf planet Ceres|journal= Nature|date=1 September 2016|doi= 10.1038/nature.2016.20526}}{{cite journal|last1=Ruesch|first1= O.|last2=Platz|first2= T.|last3=Schenk|first3= P.|last4=McFadden|first4=L. A.|last5=Castillo-Rogez|first5=J. C.|last6=Quick|first6=L. C.|last7=Byrne|first7= S.|last8=Preusker|first8= F.|last9=OBrien|first9=D. P.|last10=Schmedemann|first10= N.|last11=Williams|first11=D. A.|last12=Li|first12=J.- Y.|last13=Bland|first13=M. T.|last14=Hiesinger|first14= H.|last15=Kneissl|first15=T.|last16=Neesemann|first16= A.|last17=Schaefer|first17= M.|last18=Pasckert|first18=J. H.|last19=Schmidt|first19=B. E.|last20=Buczkowski|first20=D. L.|last21=Sykes|first21=M. V.|last22=Nathues|first22= A.|last23=Roatsch|first23= T.|last24=Hoffmann|first24= M.|last25=Raymond|first25=C. A.|last26=Russell|first26=C. T.|title=Cryovolcanism on Ceres|journal= Science|volume= 353|issue= 6303|date= 2016-09-02|pages= aaf4286–aaf4286|doi= 10.1126/science.aaf4286|bibcode = 2016Sci...353.4286R }} It is the closest cryovolcano to the Sun yet discovered.{{Cite news|url=http://go.galegroup.com/ps/i.do?p=AONE&sw=w&u=mcc_pv&v=2.1&id=GALE%7CA480142011&it=r&asid=65778ea5e8a6f047a74e50ad58b05897 |title=The Mystery of Ahuna Mons, The Lonely Ice Volcano|last=|first=|date=23 January 2017|newspaper=States News Service|access-date=12 February 2017|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|work=|via=Gale}} It is roughly antipodal to the largest impact basin on Ceres, {{convert|280|km|mi|abbr=on}} diameter [[Kerwan (crater)|Kerwan]]. Seismic energy from the Kerwan-forming impact may have been focused on the opposite side of Ceres, fracturing the outer layers of the area and facilitating the movement of high viscosity cryovolcanic magma (consisting of muddy water ice softened by its content of salts) that was then extruded onto the surface. Crater counts suggest that formation of the mountain continued into the last several hundred million years, making this a relatively young geological feature. ==Gallery== [[File:PIA21919-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-AhunaMons-20180314.jpg|thumb|center|600px|
Ahuna Mons (14 March 2018)
Significant amounts of [[sodium carbonate]] have been detected
(locations noted by the red and green coloring in the bottom right image).
]] [[File:PIA22769-CeresDwarfPlanet-AhunaMons-LastLooks-20181101.jpg|thumb|center|600px|
[[Dawn (spacecraft)#Mission conclusion|Last view from ''Dawn'']] (1 November 2018){{cite web |last1=Brown |first1=Dwayne |last2=Wendel |first2=JoAnna |last3=McCartney |first3=Gretchen |title=The Legacy of NASA's Dawn, Near End of Mission |url=https://www.nasa.gov/feature/jpl/the-legacy-of-nasa-s-dawn-near-end-of-mission |date=6 September 2018 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=2 November 2018 }}{{cite news |last1=Brown |first1=Dwayne |last2=Wendel |first2=JoAnna |last3=McCartney |first3=Gretchen |title=NASA's Dawn Mission to Asteroid Belt Comes to End |url=https://www.jpl.nasa.gov/news/news.php?feature=7275 |date=1 November 2018 |work=[[NASA]] |accessdate=2 November 2018 }}{{cite news |last=Chang |first=Kenneth |title=NASA’s Dawn Mission to the Asteroid Belt Says Good Night - Launched in 2007, the spacecraft discovered bright spots on Ceres and forbidding terrain on Vesta. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/11/01/science/nasa-dawn-ceres-vesta-asteroids-end.html |date=1 November 2018 |work=[[The New York Times]] |accessdate=2 November 2018 }}
]] Image:PIA19578-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-2ndMappingOrbit-image10-20150614-rotated180.jpg|Ceres viewed by [[Dawn (spacecraft)|''Dawn'']]. The north face of Ahuna Mons projects above the center of the limb. North is down. Image:PIA19574-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-2ndMappingOrbit-image6-20150606-crop300to400.jpg|Context view of the mountain surrounded by lightly cratered terrain. [[Bright spots on Ceres]] can be seen at 11:00. North is up. Image:PIA19995-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-3rdMapOrbit-HAMO-image53-20150928.jpg|Context view of Ahuna Mons (upper left)
(28 September 2015). Image:PIA20130-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-3rdMapOrbit-HAMO-image67-20151014.jpg|Context view of Ahuna Mons (upper right)
(14 October 2015). Image:PIA20579-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-image84-20160320.jpg|Close-up view
(20 March 2016). Image:PIA19618-Ceres-PyramidShapedMountain-Dawn-20150806.jpg|Computer-generated image of Ahuna Mons
Elevation exaggerated by five (6 August 2015). {{multiple image|caption_align=center | align = center | direction = horizontal | background color = | header_background = | header_align = | header = Ahuna Mons - [[Terrain cartography|Topographical views (March 2016)]] | width = | image1 = PIA20399-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-AhunaMons-rel20160311.jpg | width1 = 255 | alt1 = | link1 = File:PIA20399-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-AhunaMons-rel20160311.jpg | caption1 = Overhead view | image2 = PIA20399-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-AhunaMons-SideView-rel20160311.jpg | width2 = 500 | alt2 = | link2 = File:PIA20399-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-AhunaMons-SideView-rel20160311.jpg | caption2 = Side view | footer_background = | footer_align = | footer = }} {{multiple image|caption_align=center | align = center | direction = horizontal | background color = | header_background = | header_align = | header = Ahuna Mons - [[Dawn (spacecraft)#Mapping orbits|LAMO views (December 2015)]] | width = | image1 = PIA20348-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-AhunaMons-201512.jpg | width1 = 153 | alt1 = | link1 = File:PIA20348-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-AhunaMons-201512.jpg | caption1 = Overhead view | image2 = PIA20349-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-AhunaMons-SideView-201512.jpg | width2 = 300 | alt2 = | link2 = File:PIA20349-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-AhunaMons-SideView-201512.jpg | caption2 = Side view | image3 = PIA20349-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-AhunaMons-3Dview-201512.jpg | width3 = 300 | alt3 = | link3 = File:PIA20349-Ceres-DwarfPlanet-Dawn-4thMapOrbit-LAMO-AhunaMons-3Dview-201512.jpg | caption3 = 3D view | footer_background = | footer_align = | footer = }} ===Animations=== {{multiple image |header=Ceres flyover animations |caption_align=center |align=center |width=250 |direction=horizontal |image1=Video-FlyOver-DwarfPlanet-Ceres--Dawn-20150608.ogv |caption1=

}} == See also == {{commons category|Ahuna Mons}} * [[List of geological features on Ceres]] * [[List of tallest mountains in the Solar System]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} == External links== * [http://astrobob.areavoices.com/2015/08/27/new-view-of-ceres-conical-mountain-a-puzzler/ New View Of Ceres Conical Mountain A Puzzler], Bog King *{{Cite APOD |date=19 March 2016|title=3D Ahuna Mons}} *{{Cite APOD |date=9 October 2017|title=Unusual Mountain Ahuna Mons on Asteroid Ceres}} {{Ceres|state=collapsed}} [[Category:Extraterrestrial mountains]] [[Category:Extraterrestrial volcanoes]] [[Category:Surface features of Ceres]] [[Category:Articles containing video clips]]

{{Infobox settlement |name = Al Khadraniyah |other_name = |native_name = |settlement_type = Town |image_skyline = |imagesize = |image_caption = |pushpin_map = |pushpin_label_position =right |pushpin_map_caption = |subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] |subdivision_name ={{flag|Iraq}} |subdivision_type1 =[[Governorates of Iraq|Governorate]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Saladin Governorate|Saladin]] |subdivision_type2 =[[Districts of Iraq|District]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Al-Shirqat district|Al-Shirqat]] |coordinates = {{coord|35|36|39|N|43|14|26|E|display=inline,title}} }} '''Al Khadraniyah''' is a village in [[Iraq]]. It is located west of River [[Tigris]] and north of [[Al-Shirqat]]. From 2014 until November 2016, it was under control of [[ISIL]].
==Location== Al-Khadraniyah(Al Khaḑrānīyah) is located at 35° 36' 39" [[North]], 43° 14' 26" [[East]], near [[Al-Shirqat|Sharqat]],<ref>[http://geolocated.org/IQ/5g6p3imh Al Khadraniyah].</ref> and the [[ruins]] of ancient [[Assur]].<ref>[https://itouchmap.com/?c=iz&UF=-3107225&UN=-4388748&DG=PPL Places in Iraq » Al Khadraniyah, Iraq].</ref>
The town is off the [[Mosul]] to [[Tikrit]] road, on the banks of the [[Tigris River]].<ref>[http://www.maplandia.com/iraq/neineva/al-khadraniyah/ Al Khadraniyah Map — Satellite Images of Al Khadraniyah].</ref> The town is services by a railway station and the border between [[Nineveh Governorate]] and [[Al-Shirqat District]] of [[Saladin Governorate]] passes through the town.
==History== In 1918 the [[Battle of Sharqat]] was fought to the south of the town. In 2014 the town was captured by the [[Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant]], and [[Battle of Mosul (2016)|retaken]] by the [[Iraqi Security Forces]] in November 2016.
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Iraq-geo-stub}}
[[Category:Geography of Iraq]]

[[File:1523482502 aa403e36a3 o.jpg|thumb|right|[[Bratislava Castle]] hill]]
'''Bratislava Foothills''' ({{lang-sk|Bratislavské predhorie}}) is a small [[mountain range]] located in [[Bratislava]], the capital of [[Slovakia]]. It is part of the [[Devín Carpathians]] mountain range,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.skgeodesy.sk/files/slovensky/ugkk/geodezia-kartografia/standardizacia-geografickeho-nazvoslovia/nazvy-vrchov-dolin-priesmykov-sediel/geomorfologicke-jednotky.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-03-15 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316113523/http://www.skgeodesy.sk/files/slovensky/ugkk/geodezia-kartografia/standardizacia-geografickeho-nazvoslovia/nazvy-vrchov-dolin-priesmykov-sediel/geomorfologicke-jednotky.pdf |archivedate=2017-03-16 |df= }} </ref> located in the northwest of the city. Mean altitude of the mountain range is 250 [[metres above sea level]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ekologie.upol.cz/ad/tuf/pdf/papers/Holecova+2012-Biodiversity.pdf |format=PDF |title=Biodiversity of soil micro- and macrofauna in oak-hornbeam forest ecosystem on the territory of Bratislava |website=Ekologie.upol.cz |accessdate=2017-03-18}}</ref>
==Peaks== * Bratislava Castle hill - features the [[Bratislava Castle]] * Napoleon's hill * Somársky vrch * Bôrik - features the Bôrik Protected Area * Slavín - features the [[Slavín]] war memorial * Murmannova výšina * Kalvária * Machnáč
==See also== * [[Geography of Bratislava]] * [[Little Carpathians]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Landforms of Slovakia]] [[Category:Geography of Bratislava]]

'''Cadore''' ({{IPA-it|kaˈdoːre}}; {{lang-lld|Cadòr}}; {{lang-vec|italic=yes|Cadór}} or, rarely, ''Cadòria''; {{lang-de|italic=yes|Cadober}} or ''Kadober''; [[Sappada]] German: ''Kadour'';<ref>[http://issuu.com/costantino_t/docs/k_s-i_ok Dizionario Sappadino-Italiano:] K.</ref> {{lang-fur|Cjadovri}}) is a [[historical region]] in the [[Italy|Italian]] region of [[Veneto]], in the northernmost part of the [[province of Belluno]] bordering on [[Austria]], the [[Trentino-Alto Adige/Südtirol]] and [[Friuli-Venezia Giulia]]. It is watered by the [[Piave River]] which has its source in the [[Carnic Alps]].<ref name=EB1911>{{cite EB1911 |wstitle=Titian |volume=26 |page=1023}}</ref> Once an undeveloped and poor district, the former ''contado'' (countship) of Cadore now has a thriving economy based on [[tourism]] and a small [[Manufacturing|manufacturing industry]], specialising in the production of [[glasses]].
The celebrated [[Renaissance]] painter [[Titian]] was born in Cadore, probably in 1488–90, one of a family of four born to Gregorio Vecelli, a distinguished councillor and soldier<ref name=EB1911/> descended from the counts. The painter's birthplace in [[Pieve di Cadore]], in a locality named ''Arsenale'' between the castle and the village Sotto Castello, is open to visitors. Titian's wife, Cecilia, was also born in Cadore, the daughter of a barber.
== History == [[File:Bandiera Cadore.jpg|thumb|right|Palace and flag of Magnifica Comunità Cadorina]] Originally populated by people who spoke [[Proto-Italic language|Proto-Italic]], [[Euganei]] and then by the Celtic [[Gauls]], the area now known as Cadore was later conquered by the [[Roman Republic|Romans]] during the second century BC and became part of the [[Italia (Roman province)|Regio X ''Venetia et Histria'']].
In the [[Late Antiquity]] era, Cadore was occupied by [[Decline of the Roman Empire|invading Germanic populations]] and was first declared part of the [[Duchy of Carinthia]] and finally, in 1077, part of the [[Patriarchate of Aquileia (State)|Patriarchate of Aquileia]]. From 1135 to 1335, Cadore was ruled by the da Camino family, the Counts of Cadore, who later became the ''Signori'' family of [[Treviso]]. It was briefly annexed to [[County of Tyrol|Tyrol]] and again was ceded to the [[Patriarchs of Aquileia]]. However, the ''[[Comune|comuni]]'' of Cadore always enjoyed a certain degree of self-government.
When the [[Republic of Venice]] conquered the neighbouring [[Friuli]] region in 1420 and put an end to the [[State (polity)|temporal power]] of the Patriarchs, the rulers of Cadore were forced to choose between aligning with Venetia or the [[Holy Roman Empire|Imperial]]. It declared its loyalty to the former, becoming one of many parts of the ''Terra ferma'', admininistered by a local ''[[podestà]]''.
The conflict between Venice and the Empire broke out again at the beginning of the 16th century, during the [[War of the League of Cambrai]]. The Venetians and the Cadorines defeated [[Maximilian I, Holy Roman Emperor]] in 1508 at the [[Battle of Valle di Cadore]], and again in 1509. Then, in 1511, Maximilian conquered the town of [[Cortina d'Ampezzo]], which was once and for all assigned to the Empire in 1516. Cortina, formerly considered part of Cadore, has since developed a distinct identity. [[File:Titian house pieve cadore 1.JPG|thumb|right|Titian house - Pieve di Cadore]] Cadore remained part of the Venetian Republic until the [[Napoleonic War]]. A famous Venetian incumbent of the local post of ''Commisario del Cadore'' ('Commissioner'; in 1589) was [[Paolo Paruta]]. [[Napoleon I Bonaparte]] created a [[duché grand-fief]], a rare, hereditary but nominal honor of ducal rank (extinguished in 1893) for his minister and admiral [[Jean-Baptiste Nompère de Champagny]].
Being a part of the [[Kingdom of Lombardy-Venetia]], Cadore was ruled by the [[Austrian Empire]] until 1866, when it was finally conquered by the newly formed [[Italy|Kingdom of Italy]] in the [[Unification of Italy|Third War of Independence]]. During the [[First World War]], Cadore was on the [[Alpine Front]] and was the scene of many battles.
==''Comuni'' of Cadore== Cadore is generally subdivided into [[Comelico]], [[Sappada]], [[Central Cadore]] and [[Boite Valley]]. The Cadore mountain community includes 22 [[comune|comuni]]: [[File:Misurina1.jpg|thumb|right|[[Tre Cime di Lavaredo]] ([[Cadorino dialect]]: ''Tré Thìme'') and [[Lake Misurina]] (''Meśorìna'') ]] *[[Auronzo di Cadore]] *[[Borca di Cadore]] *[[Calalzo di Cadore]] *[[Cibiana di Cadore]] *[[Comelico Superiore]] *[[Danta di Cadore]] *[[Domegge di Cadore]] *[[Lorenzago di Cadore]] *[[Lozzo di Cadore]] *[[Ospitale di Cadore]] *[[Perarolo di Cadore]] *[[Pieve di Cadore]] *[[San Nicolò di Comelico]] *[[San Pietro di Cadore]] *[[Santo Stefano di Cadore]] *[[San Vito di Cadore]] *[[Sappada]] *[[Selva di Cadore]] *[[Valle di Cadore]] *[[Vigo di Cadore]] *[[Vodo di Cadore]] *[[Zoppè di Cadore]]
==See also== * [[Titian]] * [[Tre Cime di Lavaredo]] * [[Lake Misurina]] * [[Antelao|Antelao mountain]] * [[Cadorino dialect]] * [[Alpine Brigade Cadore]]
==Sources and references==

{{Refimprove|date=August 2013}} {{Politics of Lithuania}} __NOTOC__ The territory of [[Lithuania]] is divided into '''10 counties''' ([[Lithuanian language|Lithuanian]]: singular ''apskritis'', plural ''apskritys''), all named after their capitals. The counties are divided into [[Municipalities of Lithuania|60 municipalities]] (Lithuanian: singular ''savivaldybė'', plural ''savivaldybės''): 9 city municipalities, 43 district municipalities and 8 municipalities. Each municipality is then divided into [[elderate]]s (Lithuanian: singular ''seniūnija'', plural ''seniūnijos''). This division was created in 1994 and slightly modified in 2000. Until 2010, the counties were administered by county governors (Lithuanian: singular – ''apskrities viršininkas'', plural – ''apskrities viršininkai'') appointed by the central government in [[Vilnius]]. Their primary duty was to ensure that the municipalities obey the laws and the [[Constitution of Lithuania]]. They did not have great powers vested in them, and so it was suggested that 10 counties are too much for Lithuania as the two smallest counties administer only four municipalities. Therefore, on 1 July 2010, the county administrations were abolished but the counties are retained for statistical and reporting purposes.{{cite web|title=Dėl apskričių viršininkų administracijų likvidavimo|url=http://www3.lrs.lt/pls/inter3/dokpaieska.showdoc_l?p_id=392936|publisher=Seimas of the Republic of Lithuania|accessdate=21 August 2011}} Modern ''apskritys'' should not be confused with ''apskritys'' that existed in the independent Lithuania during the [[interwar period]]. At that time Lithuania had a two-tier administrative division: ''apskritys'' that were subdivided into ''valsčius''. Lithuania now has a three-step division: counties, municipalities, and elderates (''apskritys'', ''savivaldybės'', and ''seniūnijos''). See [[subdivisions of Lithuania]] for details. ==Map== This map shows counties as well as municipalities. Eight city municipalities and two municipalities are marked by numbers: {| |- |valign=top width=225px| 1{{spaced ndash}}[[Vilnius City Municipality]]

page.title: Crimean journey of Catherine the Great

revision.comment: Robot - Moving category 1787 in Russia‎ to [[:Category:1787 in the Russian Empire]] per [[WP:CFD|CFD]] at [[Wikipedia:Categories_for_discussion/Log/2018_January_20]].
revision.text:
[[File:Plersch Night illumination of Kaniów.jpg|thumb|right|300px|A night illumination in honor of Catherine the Great on the Dnieper River]] The '''Crimean journey of Catherine the Great''' ({{lang-ru|Путешествие Екатерины II в Крым}}, also known as Таврический вояж ('''[[Taurida]] Voyage''') at the time) was a six-month (January 2, 1787 — July 11, 1787) inspection trip of [[Catherine the Great|Catherine II of Russia]] to the newly acquired lands of [[New Russia]] and [[Crimea]], gained as a result of the victorious wars against the [[Ottoman Empire]] ([[Russo-Turkish War, 1735-1739|1735–39]] and [[Russo-Turkish War, 1768-1774|1768–74]]) and peace treaties with the [[Cossack Hetmanate]] followed by the forced liquidation of free [[Zaporizhian Sich]]. The trip was carried out with her court and several ambassadors. During the trip she met with the Austrian emperor [[Joseph II, Holy Roman Emperor|Joseph II]], travelling incognito. The trip was arranged by [[Gregory Potemkin]], a favorite and lover of Catherine II. The trip happened when the [[Russo-Turkish War (1787–92)]] was just about to erupt.<ref>[[Alexander Brückner]], ''Potyomkin'', С.-Петербург. Издание К.Л. Риккера 1891, [http://adjudant.ru/potemkin/brikner05.htm Chapter V: Путешествие Екатерины (1787 г.)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080109184010/http://adjudant.ru/potemkin/brikner05.htm |date=2008-01-09 }}</ref>
Since these times the expression "[[Potemkin village]]" came into being, referring to the legend<ref>[http://www.straightdope.com/columns/read/2479/did-potemkin-villages-really-exist "Did "Potemkin villages" really exist?"], ''[[Straight Dope]]''</ref> about fake villages hastily erected by Potemkin along the Catherine's route, in order to impress the Empress.
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading==
*[http://www.hrono.ru/libris/lib_s/segur5.html Russian translation] of the memoir of [[Louis Philippe, comte de Ségur]] who took the trip as a French ambassador; see also [http://www.vidania.ru/temple/krym/o_puteshestvii_ekateriny_vtoroy_v_krym.html here]
[[Category:Catherine the Great]] [[Category:1787 in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:Crimea in the Russian Empire]] [[Category:Voyages]]
{{Ukraine-hist-stub}} {{Russia-hist-stub}}

{{EngvarB|date=April 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} [[Image:LocationEastMalaysia.png|thumb|300px|alt=A black and white general world map with East Malaysia highlighted in green|right|East Malaysia comprises the states of Sabah and Sarawak, and the Federal territory of Labuan.]] [[File:Borneo2 map english names.svg|thumb|300px|right|alt=A map of Borneo showing East Malaysia and its major cities. Labuan is the island off the coast of Sabah near Kota Kinabalu.|Political map of the island of Borneo, with East Malaysia shown in orange]]
'''East Malaysia''' (''Malaysia Timur''), also known as '''[[Sabah]], [[Sarawak]] and [[Labuan]]''' (''Sabah, Sarawak dan Labuan'')<ref>The latter term is more commonly used in Malaysia to avoid the connotation of "East Malaysia" and "West Malaysia" ([[Peninsular Malaysia]]) being two separate countries, as in former [[East Germany]] and [[West Germany]].</ref> or '''Malaysian Borneo''',<ref>{{Cite news|title=Malaysia urged to scrap coal plant in eco-sensitive Borneo|date=7 July 2010|publisher=AFP|accessdate=8 July 2010|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5j8XrzbzMEHI_Mb5D1IHsGoveMMeA}}</ref> is the part of [[Malaysia]] on the island of [[Borneo]], the world's third largest island. It consists of the [[States of Malaysia|Malaysian states]] of [[Sabah]], closer to the [[Philippines]] than the west of the country, [[Sarawak]] in the west and the [[Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territory]] of [[Labuan]]. Labuan is an island in its small archipelago of the same name due north of [[Brunei]]; its closest land mass is with Sabah.<ref>http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:L:2006:354:0019:0028:EN:PDF</ref> It lies to the east of [[Peninsular Malaysia]] (West Malaysia), the part of the country on the [[Malay Peninsula]]. The two are separated by the [[South China Sea]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.malaysiatravel.org.uk/geography.html|title=Location|publisher=Malaysia Travel.org.uk|accessdate=7 July 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100923131937/http://malaysiatravel.org.uk/geography.html|archivedate=23 September 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/Malay+Peninsula|title=Malay Peninsula|publisher=HarperCollins Publishers|accessdate=7 July 2010}}</ref>
East Malaysia is less populated and overall less developed in its settlements than its West which contains [[Kuala Lumpur]] and [[Penang]] however its land mass is larger and it has more of many natural resources including oil and gas reserves. City status award is restrained in the pan-regional style so reserved to [[Kuching]], [[Kota Kinabalu]], and [[Miri, Malaysia|Miri]]; [[Victoria, Labuan]] for example is an [[Offshore Financial Centre]] and major port. In ecology it has a significant proportion of the biodiverse [[Borneo lowland rain forests]] and [[Borneo montane rain forests]].
==History== {{see also|History of Sabah|History of Sarawak|History of Labuan|British Borneo}} Some parts of present-day East Malaysia, especially the coastal regions, were once part of the [[thalassocracy]] of the [[Sultanate of Brunei]].<ref>{{citation |title=A History of Brunei |page=45 |publisher=RoutlegdeCurzon |year=2002 |author=Saunders, Graham E. |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SQ4t_OJgSjAC&pg=PA40 |accessdate=5 October 2009|isbn=9780700716982 }}</ref> However, most parts of the interior region consisted of independent tribal societies.
In 1658, the northern and eastern coasts of Sabah were ceded to the [[Sultanate of Sulu]] while the west coast of Sabah and most of Sarawak remained part of Brunei. Beginning in the mid 19th century, Sabah and Sarawak became British protectorates, and, in 1946, they became separate British colonies.
==Federation== Sabah (formerly [[British North Borneo]]) and Sarawak were separate [[Crown colony|British colonies]] from [[British Malaya|Malaya]], and did not become part of the [[Federation of Malaya]] in 1957. However, each voted to become part of the new [[Malaysia|Federation of Malaysia]] along with the [[Federation of Malaya]] and Singapore in 1963. Previously, there were efforts to unite [[Brunei]], Sabah, and Sarawak under the [[North Borneo Federation]] but that failed after the [[Brunei Revolt]] occurred.
Sabah and Sarawak retained a higher degree of local government and legislative autonomy than other states in West Malaysia. For example, both states have their own immigration controls, requiring Malaysian citizens from West Malaysia to carry passports or identity cards when visiting East Malaysia.
The islands of [[Labuan]] were once part of [[North Borneo]] (later [[Sabah]]) in 1946 before becoming a [[Federal Territories (Malaysia)|Federal Territory]] in Malaysia on 1984. It was used to establish a centre for [[Offshore Financial Centre|offshore finance]] in 1990.
Since 2010, there has been some speculation and discussion, at least on the ground level, about the possibility of secession from the Federation of Malaysia<ref>[http://www.malaysia-today.net/mtcolumns/newscommentaries/30977-push-for-sabah-swaks-independence-next-stop-un- Push for Sabah, S'wak's independence: Next stop UN] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120907203736/http://www.malaysia-today.net/mtcolumns/newscommentaries/30977-push-for-sabah-swaks-independence-next-stop-un- |date=7 September 2012 }}. Malaysia-today.net (2010-04-02). Retrieved on 2013-07-29.</ref> because of allegations of resource mishandling, illegal processing of immigrants, etc.<ref>http://www.sarawakwatch.com/?p=13661{{Dead link|date=December 2012}}</ref>
==Administration== It has been a source of debate whether the states of Sabah and Sarawak joined the Federation of Malaysia as equal partners with Malaya and Singapore or whether they became merely equal partners of the states of Malaya (Peninsular Malaysia).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=72641|title='Know Federal System' advice|publisher=Daily Express|date=21 May 2010|accessdate=9 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110621233347/http://www.dailyexpress.com.my/news.cfm?NewsID=72641|archivedate=21 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The consensus seems to be that Sabah and Sarawak are merely states of the federation with a slightly higher degree of autonomy compared to states in Peninsular Malaysia. For example, the East Malaysian states have separate laws regulating the entry of citizens from other states in Malaysia (including the other East Malaysian state), whereas, in Peninsular Malaysia, there are no restrictions on interstate travel or migration, including visitors from East Malaysia. There are also separate [[Property law|land law]]s governing Sabah and Sarawak, as opposed to the National Land Code, which governs Peninsular Malaysia.
With regard to the administration of justice, the courts in East Malaysia are part of the federal court system in Malaysia. The Constitution of Malaysia provides that there shall be two [[High Courts of Malaysia|High Courts]] of co-ordinate jurisdiction – The High Court in Malaya and the High Court in Sabah and Sarawak (formerly the High Court in Borneo). The current Chief Judge of Sabah and Sarawak is [[David Wong Dak Wah]] from Sabah. His office is the fourth highest in the Malaysian judicial system (behind the Chief Judge of Malaya, President of the [[Court of Appeal of Malaysia|Court of Appeal]], and [[Chief Justice of Malaysia]]).
==Politics== In 1976, all the Sabah and Sarawak MPs supported the Malaysian parliament bill which downgraded both the states from equal partners to one of the 13 states in the federation.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Chia|first1=Jonathan|title=All round aye from Sabah, Sarawak|url=http://www.theborneopost.com/2016/10/19/all-round-aye-from-sabah-sarawak/|accessdate=20 October 2016|publisher=The Borneo Post|date=19 October 2016|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019084005/http://www.theborneopost.com/2016/10/19/all-round-aye-from-sabah-sarawak/|archivedate=19 October 2016}}</ref> Sarawak, Sabah and Labuan currently holding a total of 57 out 222 seats (25.68%) in the [[Parliament of Malaysia|Malaysian parliament]] with majority of the seats going to the ruling coalition [[Barisan Nasional]] ever since the two states hold their first state elections. However, [[Jeffrey Kitingan]] from Sabah, who is vocal of East Malaysian rights, is concerned that the number of seats from East Malaysia is under-represented in the Malaysian parliament as compared to the ideal representation of 35% stated in the [[Cobbold Commission#Report|Cobbold Commission report]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2012/03/08/sabah-sarawaks-right-to-have-35-more-seats/|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714133812/http://www.freemalaysiatoday.com/category/nation/2012/03/08/sabah-sarawaks-right-to-have-35-more-seats/|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 July 2014|title=‘Sabah, Sarawak’s ‘right’ to have more parliament seats’|last=Rintod|first=Luke|date=8 March 2012|work=|publisher=[[Free Malaysia Today]]|accessdate=16 June 2014}}</ref> After the conclusion of [[Malaysian general election, 2013|2013 Malaysian general election]], East Malaysia contributed a total of 47 parliamentary seats (35.34%) out of the 133 seats won by the Barisan Nasional coalition following the Barisan dismal performance in [[Peninsular Malaysia]]. This has resulted an increase in ministers and deputy ministers allocation for East Malaysia in the [[Cabinet of Malaysia|Malaysian Cabinet]] from 11 out of 57 portfolios in [[Malaysian general election, 2008|2008 election]] to 20 out of 61 after the 2013 election.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mysinchew.com/node/86472|title=20 ministers, deputy ministers from East Malaysia|last=|first=|date=16 May 2013|work=|publisher=[[Sin Chew Daily]]|accessdate=16 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714133156/http://www.mysinchew.com/node/86472|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/230262|title=The new cabinet, by party and in numbers|last=|first=|date=15 May 2013|work=|publisher=[[Malaysiakini]]|accessdate=16 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714170302/http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/230262|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> On the basis that East Malaysia should be treated as an equal partner as compared to the Peninsular, local lawmakers have urged the federal government since the year 2011 to appoint at least one deputy prime minister from East Malaysia to the federal cabinet.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/east-malaysian-dpm-gratuitous-says-dr-m|title=East Malaysian DPM gratuitous, says Dr M|last=Chieh|first=Yow Hong|date=27 October 2011|work=|publisher=[[The Malaysian Insider]]|accessdate=16 June 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140714123621/http://www.themalaysianinsider.com/malaysia/article/east-malaysian-dpm-gratuitous-says-dr-m|archivedate=14 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/265748|title=Appoint DPMs from East M'sia, Putrajaya urged|last=|first=|date=15 June 2014|work=|publisher=[[Malaysiakini]]|accessdate=16 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140616070954/http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/265748|archivedate=16 June 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Political parties in Sarawak and Sabah evolved independently of each other. [[Party switching]] and party leadership tussles are common in both the states.
==Physical geography== [[File:Borneo Topography.png|right|thumb|A topographic map of Borneo with East Malaysia located on the northern portion of the island]] The landscape of East Malaysia is mostly [[Borneo lowland rain forests|lowland rain forests]] with areas of [[Borneo montane rain forests|mountain rain forest]] towards the hinterland.
The total area of East Malaysia is 198,447 km<sup>2</sup>, representing approximately 60% of the total land area of [[Malaysia]] and 26.4% of the total area of [[Borneo]], which is 50% bigger than [[Peninsular Malaysia]] at {{convert|132156|km2|sqmi}}, comparable with [[South Dakota]] or [[Great Britain]].
East Malaysia contains the five highest [[List of mountains in Malaysia|mountains in Malaysia]], the highest being [[Mount Kinabalu]] at 4095 m, which is also the highest mountain in Borneo and the 10th highest mountain peak in Southeast Asia. It also contains the two longest rivers in Malaysia – [[Rajang River]] and [[Kinabatangan River]].<ref name="geo">{{Citation|title=Geography|url=http://www.malaysiahistorical.com.my/geography.html|date=|accessdate=16 July 2010|publisher=Malaysiahistorical.com.my|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100427065735/http://www.malaysiahistorical.com.my/geography.html|archivedate=27 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
[[Banggi Island]] in [[Sabah]] and [[Bruit Island]] in [[Sarawak]] are the two largest islands that are located entirely within Malaysia.<ref name=geo /> The largest island is Borneo, which is shared with [[Indonesia]] and [[Brunei]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asianbiketour.com/Motorcycle_tour_Asia_BORNEO_East_Malaysia_Tour_6.htm|title=Motorcycle tour description and itinerary for the Borneo-East Malaysia motorcycle tour.|publisher=Asian Bike Tour|accessdate=20 July 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100402005421/http://www.asianbiketour.com/Motorcycle_tour_Asia_BORNEO_East_Malaysia_Tour_6.htm|archivedate=2 April 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The second largest island is [[Sebatik Island]], in Sabah, which is shared with Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.borneotourgigant.com/Kakaban.html|title=Dive The Kakaban Island|publisher=De 'Gigant Tours|accessdate=20 July 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515095950/http://www.borneotourgigant.com/Kakaban.html|archivedate=15 May 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.exroyalmarinesbandsmen.net/NOTICEBOARD/wright.htm|title=Sebatik Island off Sabah, Malaysia 1965|publisher=The Band of Her Majesty's Royal Marines|accessdate=20 July 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717133821/http://www.exroyalmarinesbandsmen.net/NOTICEBOARD/wright.htm|archivedate=17 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Sarawak contains the [[Mulu Caves]] within [[Gunung Mulu National Park]]. Its [[Sarawak Chamber]] is the largest known cave chamber in the world. The Gunung Mulu National Park was declared a [[UNESCO]] [[World Heritage Site]] in November 2000.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1013|title=Gunung Mulu National Park|publisher=UNESCO.org|accessdate=20 July 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016060027/http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1013|archivedate=16 October 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Sabah's attractions include World Heritage Site [[Kinabalu Park]] (which includes [[Mount Kinabalu]]),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&id_site=1012|title=Kinabalu Park|publisher=UNESCO.org|accessdate=20 July 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100614212731/http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&id_site=1012|archivedate=14 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> and [[Sipadan|Sipadan Island]] (a diving and bio-diversity hot-spot).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://aquaviews.net/diving-at-sipadan-island-borneo-an-untouched-piece-of-art/|title=Diving at Sipadan Island, Borneo – An Untouched Piece of Art|author=Noreen |date=10 January 2010|publisher=Aquaviews: Online Scuba Magazine|accessdate=20 July 2010}}</ref>
==Geology== Several oil and gas fields have been discovered offshore, including the Samarang [[oil field]] (1972) offshore Sabah, the Baronia oil field (1967) offshore Sarawak, and the Central Luconia [[natural gas field]]s (1968), also offshore Sarawak.<ref name=Scherer>Scherer, F.C., 1980, Exploration in East Malaysia Over the Past Decade, in Giant Oil and Gas Fields of the Decade, AAPG Memoir 30, Halbouty, M.T., editor, Tulsa, American Association of Petroleum Geologists, {{ISBN|0891813063}}, p. 424</ref> The Baronia Field is a [[Dome (geology)|domal]] [[structural trap]] between two east-west growth [[fault (geology)|faults]], which produces from late [[Miocene]] [[sandstones]] interbedded with [[siltstone]]s and [[clay]]s at 2 km depth in 75 m of water.<ref name=Scherer/>{{rp|431}} The Samarang Field produces from late Miocene sandtones in an alternating sequence of sandstones, siltstones and clays in an [[anticline]] at a depth of about 3 km in water 9–45 m.<ref name=Scherer/>{{rp|431}} The Central Luconia Gas Fields produce from middle to late Miocene [[carbonate platform]] and pinnacle reefs from 1.25-3.76 km deep and water depths 60-100m.<ref name=Scherer/>{{rp|436–437}}
==Population== {{Pie chart |thumb = right |caption = Ethnicity in East Malaysia (2015) |title= |label1 = Indigenous / Non - Malay Bumiputera |value1 = 50.9 |color1 = Blue |label2 = Non - Malaysian Citizen |value2 = 17.8 |color2 = LightGrey |label3 = Chinese |value3 = 14.7 |color3 = Red |label4 = Bumiputera (Malay) |value4 = 14.4 |color4 = Green |label5 = Others |value5 = 1.9 |color5 = Yellow |label6 = Indian |value6 = 0.3 |color6 = Orange }} {{bar box |title=Religion in East Malaysia – 2010 Census |titlebar= |left1=Religion |right1=Percent |float=right |bars= {{bar percent|[[Islam]]|Green|51.3}} {{bar percent|[[Christianity]]|Blue|33.3}} {{bar percent|[[Buddhism]]|yellow|9.3}} {{bar percent|[[Chinese folk religion]]|Magenta|2.6}} {{bar percent|Unknown / None|Brown|1.6}} {{bar percent|[[Irreligion|No religion]]|Black|1.3}} {{bar percent|Others|Gray|0.5}} {{bar percent|[[Hinduism]]|orange|0.1}} }} The total population of East Malaysia in 2010 was 5.77 million (3.21 million in Sabah, 2.47 million in Sarawak, and 0.09 million in Labuan),<ref name="Census 2010">{{cite web |url=http://www.statistics.gov.my/portal/download_Population/files/census2010/Taburan_Penduduk_dan_Ciri-ciri_Asas_Demografi.pdf |format=PDF |work=Population Distribution and Basic Demographic Characteristics 2010 |title=Chart 3: Population distribution by state, Malaysia, 2010 |publisher=Department of Statistics, Malaysia |language=Malay, English |page=2 (p. 13 in PDF) |accessdate=13 December 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110830200524/http://www.statistics.gov.my/portal/download_Population/files/census2010/Taburan_Penduduk_dan_Ciri-ciri_Asas_Demografi.pdf |archivedate=30 August 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> which represents 20.4% of the population of Malaysia. A significant part of the population of East Malaysia today reside in towns and cities. The largest city and urban centre is [[Kuching]], which is also the capital of Sarawak and has a population of over 600,000 people. [[Kota Kinabalu]] is the second largest, and one of the most important cities in East Malaysia. Kuching, Kota Kinabalu, and [[Miri, Malaysia|Miri]] are the only three places with city status in East Malaysia. Other important towns include [[Sandakan]] and [[Tawau]] in Sabah, [[Sibu]] and [[Bintulu]] in Sarawak, and [[Victoria, Labuan|Victoria]] in Labuan.
The earliest inhabitants of East Malaysia were the [[Dayak people]] and other related ethnic groups such as the [[Kadazan-Dusun]] people. These indigenous people form a significant portion, but not the majority, of the population. For hundreds of years, there has been significant migration into East Malaysia and Borneo from many parts of the [[Malay Archipelago]], including Java, the [[Lesser Sunda Islands]], [[Sulawesi]], and [[Sulu]]. More recently, there has been immigration from [[India]] and China.
The indigenous inhabitants were originally animists. Islamic influence began as early as the 15th century, while Christian influence started in the 19th century.
The indigenous inhabitants are generally partisan and maintain culturally distinct dialects of the [[Malay language]], in addition to their own ethnic languages. Approximately 13% of the population of Sabah, and 26% of the population of Sarawak, is composed of ethnic Chinese Malaysians.
However, the demography of Sabah has been altered dramatically with the alleged implementation of [[Project IC]] in the 1990s. Citizenships are alleged to be granted to immigrants of [[Indonesia]] and [[Philippines]] in order to keep the [[United Malays National Organisation|UMNO]] ruling party in power.<ref>{{cite news|title=SPECIAL REPORT: Sabah's Project M (subscription required)|url=http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/53046|date=27 June 2006|last=|first=|publisher=[[Malaysiakini]]|accessdate=23 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140718105636/http://www.malaysiakini.com/news/53046|archivedate=18 July 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> [[Royal Commission of Inquiry on illegal immigrants in Sabah|Royal Commission of Inquiry]] (RCI) has been conducted from 11 August 2012 to 20 September 2013. The outcome of the investigation was submitted to the prime minister on 19 May 2014.<ref>{{cite news|title=RCI report on Sabah’s illegal immigrants handed to PM, Agong|url=http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/rci-report-on-sabahs-illegal-immigrants-handed-to-pm-agong|date=19 May 2014|last=|first=|publisher=[[The Malay Mail]]|accessdate=23 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140826124310/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/rci-report-on-sabahs-illegal-immigrants-handed-to-pm-agong|archivedate=26 August 2014|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The report was released on 3 December 2014 after 6 months delay. It stated that Project IC might have existed, which was responsible for a sudden spike in the state population. However, the report did not pinpoint any responsibility except for "corrupt officials" who took advantage of the system.<ref>{{cite news|title= ‘Corrupt officials’ blamed for Sabah problems, but RCI says hands tied|url= http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/corrupt-officials-blamed-for-sabah-problems-but-rci-says-hands-tied|date= 3 December 2014|last= Chi|first= Melissa|publisher= [[The Malay Mail]]|accessdate= 10 December 2014|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141225101755/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/corrupt-officials-blamed-for-sabah-problems-but-rci-says-hands-tied|archivedate= 25 December 2014|df= dmy-all}}</ref>
==Education== East Malaysia currently has two public universities, namely [[Universiti Malaysia Sarawak]] (UNIMAS) and [[Universiti Malaysia Sabah]] (UMS). [[Universiti Teknologi Mara]] (UiTM) also has branch campuses in both states. Labuan's own institution of higher education is Universiti Malaysia Sabah Labuan International Campus, which has a branch in Sepanggar Bay, Kota Kinabalu. All prospective university entrants from Sabah, Sarawak, and Labuan must sit the examinations of one matriculation college, Kolej Matrikulasi Labuan.
[[UCSI University, Sarawak Campus]], [[University College of Technology Sarawak]] (UCTS) [[Tunku Abdul Rahman University College]] (Sabah campus), [[International University College Of Technology Twintech]] (Sabah campus), and [[Open University Malaysia]] (Sabah campus) have local private university branch campuses in East Malaysia. [[Curtin University, Malaysia]] and [[Swinburne University of Technology Sarawak Campus]] are foreign university branch campuses in Sarawak.
There are 4 teacher training colleges ([[Malay language|Malay]]: ''Maktab Perguruan'') in Sarawak, and 4 teacher training colleges in Sabah.<ref>{{cite web|title=Institut Pendidikan Guru (Teachers' Training Institute)|url=http://www.moe.gov.my/my/direktori-ipg?page=2&page=1&page=2&page=1&page=2&page=1&page=2&page=1|publisher=Kementerian Pendidikan Malaysia (Malaysian Ministry of Education)|accessdate=22 December 2015|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222000249/http://www.moe.gov.my/my/direktori-ipg?page=2&page=1&page=2&page=1&page=2&page=1&page=2&page=1|archivedate=22 December 2015|quote=IPG Kampus Sarawak, IPG Kampus Tun Abdul Razak, IPG Kampus Batu Lintang(1st page), IPG Kampus Rajang (2nd page)}}</ref>
==Transport== The [[Pan Borneo Highway]] connects Sabah, Sarawak, and Brunei. The road has been poorly maintained since it was built. The narrow road is dark at night without any street lights and there are many danger spots, sharp bends, blind spots, potholes, and erosion.<ref>{{cite news |title= Repair Pan Borneo Highway now, says Bintulu MP following latest fatal accident |url= http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Community/2013/09/13/Deadly-reminder-after-grim-toll-Repair-Pan-Borneo-Highway-now-says-Bintulu-MP-following-latest-fatal.aspx/ |date= 13 September 2013 |last= Then |first= Stephen |publisher= [[The Star (Malaysia)]] |accessdate= 23 June 2014 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160206023625/http://www.thestar.com.my/news/community/2013/09/13/deadly-reminder-after-grim-toll-repair-pan-borneo-highway-now-says-bintulu-mp-following-latest-fatal/ |archivedate= 6 February 2016 |df= dmy-all }}</ref> However, federal government funds have been allocated for the upgrade of the highway, which will be carried out in stages until completion in 2025.<ref>{{cite news|title=Pan Borneo Highway project will be carried out in stages, says minister|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Community/2013/11/14/Pan-Borneo-Highway-project-will-be-carried-out-in-stages-says-minister/|date=14 November 2013|last=|first=|publisher=[[The Star (Malaysia)]]|accessdate=23 June 2014|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150904034305/http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Community/2013/11/14/Pan-Borneo-Highway-project-will-be-carried-out-in-stages-says-minister/|archivedate=4 September 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The major airports in East Malaysia are [[Kuching International Airport]], [[Labuan Airport]] and [[Kota Kinabalu International Airport]]. There are frequent air flights by carriers including [[Malaysia Airlines]] (MAS) and [[AirAsia]] between East Malaysia and Peninsular Malaysia. Other ports of entry to East Malaysia include [[Sibu Airport]], [[Bintulu Airport]], and [[Miri Airport]] in Sarawak, [[Sandakan Airport]] and [[Tawau Airport]] in Sabah. MAS also operates international flights to major cities in East Malaysia.<ref name=borneo>{{cite web|url=http://www.borneo-hotels.com/info/gettingthere.htm|title=Getting To Borneo By Air, By Car, By Train|publisher=Asia Web Direct|accessdate=15 July 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612184348/http://www.borneo-hotels.com/info/gettingthere.htm|archivedate=12 June 2011|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
The rural areas in Borneo can only be accessed by air or river boat. River transport is especially prevalent in Sarawak because there are many large and long rivers, with [[Rajang River]] being the most used. Rivers are used by boats and ferries for communications (i.e. mail) and passenger transport between inland areas and coastal towns. Timber is also transported via vessels and log carriers down the rivers of Sarawak.<ref name=borneo/>
The Labuan Ferry operates boat express and vehicle ferries from [[Labuan]] Island to [[Sabah]], [[Sarawak]] and [[Brunei]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=New Ferry launched for Labuan-Sabah-Brunei sea route|url=http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/05/02/Ferry-Labuan-Sabah-Brunei/|journal=http://www.thestar.com.my|date=2 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150505014002/http://www.thestar.com.my/News/Nation/2015/05/02/Ferry-Labuan-Sabah-Brunei/|archivedate=5 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Ferries have overtaken air travel as the chief [[Mode of transport|transportation mode]] on and off the island.
==Security== {{Main article|Cross border attacks in Sabah}} The state of Sabah has been subjected to attacks by [[Moro people|Moro]] pirates and militants since the 1960s and intensification in 1985, 2000, 2013. The [[Eastern Sabah Security Zone]] (ESSZONE) and [[Eastern Sabah Security Command]] (ESSCOM) were established on 25 March 2013 to tighten security in the region. Since 2014, a 12-hour dusk-to-dawn curfew has been imposed on six Sabah east coast districts.<ref>{{cite news |title= Sabah curfew renewed for the seventh time |url= http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/sabah-curfew-renewed-for-the-seventh-time |date= 5 November 2014 |last= Chan |first= Julia |publisher= [[The Malay Mail]] |accessdate= 6 November 2014 |deadurl= no |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20141222161922/http://www.themalaymailonline.com/malaysia/article/sabah-curfew-renewed-for-the-seventh-time |archivedate= 22 December 2014 |df= dmy-all }}</ref>

==Bibliography== * Andrew Harding & James Chin, [http://www.marshallcavendish.com/marshallcavendish/genref/50-Years-of-Malaysia_B836_Singapore.aspx 50 years of Malaysia:] Federalism revisited (Marshall Cavendish 2014) * {{sourcetext|source=Cabinet Memorandum. Policy in regard to Malaya and Borneo. Memorandum by the Secretary of State for the Colonies. 29 August 1945}} * {{sourcetext|source=Manila Accord (31 July 1963)}} * {{sourcetext|source=Exchange of notes constituting an agreement relating to the implementation of the Manila Accord of 31 July 1963}} * Acts of the Parliament of the United Kingdom {{sourcetext|source=Malaysia Act 1963}} * {{sourcetext|source=Agreement relating to Malaysia between United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Federation of Malaya, North Borneo, Sarawak and Singapore}}
